BDI-II.criteria: The BDI-II is a 21-question multiple-choice self-report inventory that is used to assess the severity of depression.

questions.question: Feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge
Not being able to stop or control worrying
Worrying too much about different things
Trouble relaxing
Being so restless that it is hard to sit still
Becoming easily annoyed or irritable
Feeling afraid as if something awful might happen

GAD-7.criteria: The GAD-7 is a 7-question multiple-choice self-report inventory that is used to assess the severity of anxiety.

questions.question: Little interest or pleasure in doing things
Feeling down, depressed, or hopeless
Trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much
Feeling tired or having little energy
Poor appetite or overeating
Feeling bad about yourself — or that you are a failure or have let yourself or your family down
Trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching TV
Moving or speaking so slowly that other people could have noticed. Or the opposite — being so fidgety or restless that you have been moving around a lot more than usual
Thoughts that you would be better off dead, or of hurting yourself

PHQ-9.criteria:
The PHQ-9 is a 9-question
multiple-choice self-report inventory that is used to assess the severity of depression.

questions.question: About how often did you feel tired out for no good reason?
About how often did you feel nervous?
About how often did you feel so nervous that nothing could calm you down?
About how often did you feel hopeless?
About how often did you feel restless or fidgety?
About how often did you feel so restless you couldn't sit still?
About how often did you feel depressed?
About how often did you feel that everything was an effort?
About how often did you feel so sad that nothing could cheer you up?
About how often did you feel worthless?

K10.criteria: The K10 is a 10-question multiple-choice self-report inventory that is used to assess the level of psychological distress.

questions.question: Have you had any recurrent, involuntary, and intrusive memories of the traumatic event(s) in the past month?
Have you had any recurrent, distressing dreams of the traumatic event(s) in the past month?
Have you acted or felt as if the traumatic event(s) were recurring (e.g., flashbacks) in the past month?
Have you had intense psychological distress or physiological reactivity to internal or external cues that symbolize or resemble an aspect of the traumatic event(s) in the past month?
Have you experienced dissociative symptoms (e.g., feeling detached from yourself or the world around you) during the traumatic event(s) in the past month?
Have you avoided or tried to avoid internal reminders of the traumatic event(s) (e.g., thoughts, feelings, memories) in the past month?
Have you avoided or tried to avoid external reminders of the traumatic event(s) (e.g., people, places, activities) in the past month?
Have you had trouble remembering important parts of the traumatic event(s) in the past month?
Have you had negative beliefs about yourself, others, or the world since the traumatic event(s)?
Have you felt persistently guilty or ashamed about the traumatic event(s)?
Have you had trouble experiencing positive emotions (e.g., happiness, love, excitement) since the traumatic event(s)?
Have you been irritable or had angry outbursts since the traumatic event(s)?
Have you had trouble sleeping since the traumatic event(s)?
Have you had trouble concentrating since the traumatic event(s)?
Have you been hypervigilant (e.g., always 'on the lookout' for danger) since the traumatic event(s)?
Have you had an exaggerated startle response (e.g., jumping or reacting strongly to sudden noises) since the traumatic event(s)?
Have you had any self-destructive behaviors (e.g., self-mutilation, suicidal ideation) since the traumatic event(s)?
Have you had any reckless or impulsive behaviors (e.g., substance abuse, reckless driving) since the traumatic event(s)?
Have you had any dissociative symptoms (e.g., feeling detached from yourself or the world around you) during the traumatic event(s)?
Have you had any derealization symptoms (e.g., feeling like the world around you is unreal) during the traumatic event(s)?
Have you had any depersonalization symptoms (e.g., feeling like you are observing yourself from outside your body) during the traumatic event(s)?
Have you had any gaps in your memory for the traumatic event(s)?
Have you had any dissociative flashbacks (e.g., feeling like you are reliving the traumatic event(s)) in the past month?
Have you had any dissociative experiences (e.g., feeling like you are in a dream or that things are not real) in the past month?
Have you had any feelings of detachment or estrangement from others since the traumatic event(s)?
Have you had any restricted range of affect (e.g., feeling numb or unable to experience emotions) since the traumatic event(s)?
Have you had any sense of a foreshortened future (e.g., feeling like you will not have a normal life span) since the traumatic event(s)?
Have you had any sleep disturbances (e.g., insomnia, nightmares) since the traumatic event(s)?
Have you had any irritability or anger outbursts since the traumatic event(s)?
Have you had any concentration problems since the traumatic event(s)?
Have you had any exaggerated startle response since the traumatic event(s)?
Have you had any hypervigilance since the traumatic event(s)?

CAPS-5.criteria: The CAPS-5 is a 20-question clinician-administered scale that assesses the severity of PTSD symptoms in adults.

questions.question: Do you feel you are a normal drinker?
Have you ever awakened the morning after some drinking the night before and found that you could not remember a part of the evening?
Does any near relative or close friend ever worry or complain about your drinking?
Can you stop drinking without difficulty after one or two drinks?
Do you ever feel guilty about your drinking?
Have you ever attended a meeting of Alcoholics Anonymous (AA)?
Have you gotten into physical fights when drinking?
Has drinking ever created problems between you and a near relative or close friend?
Has any family member or close friend gone to anyone for help about your drinking?
Have you ever lost friends because of your drinking?
Have you ever gotten into trouble at work because of drinking?
Have you ever lost a job because of drinking?
Have you ever neglected your obligations, your family, or your work for two or more days in a row because you were drinking?
Do you drink before noon fairly often?
Have you ever been told you have liver trouble such as cirrhosis?
After heavy drinking, have you ever had delirium tremens (D.T.s), severe shaking, visual or auditory (hearing) hallucinations?
Have you ever gone to anyone for help about your drinking?
Have you ever been hospitalized because of drinking?
Has your drinking ever resulted in your being hospitalized in a psychiatric ward?
Have you ever gone to any doctor, social worker, clergyman or mental health clinic for help with any emotional problem in which drinking was part of the problem?
Have you ever been arrested for drunk driving or driving after drinking?
Have you ever been arrested, even for a few hours, because of other behavior while drinking?

MAST.criteria: The MAST is a 25-question self-administered screening tool designed to identify individuals with alcohol-related problems.
